verses.text: When Jesus came down from the mountain, large crowds followed him.
verses.comment: This verse marks the transition after Jesus' Sermon on the Mount, highlighting his authority and drawing many to him.

verses.text: And behold, a leper approached him and bowed down, saying, 'Lord, if you are willing, you can make me clean.'
verses.comment: The leper's humility and faith are notable; he recognizes Jesus' divine authority over sickness (see Lev 13:45-46).

verses.text: And Jesus stretched out his hand and touched him, saying, 'I am willing; be clean.' Immediately the leprosy left him.
verses.comment: By touching the leper, Jesus demonstrates power over ritual impurity, foreshadowing the healing and sanctifying power available through him.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to him, 'See that you tell no one; but go, show yourself to the priest and present the offering Moses commanded, as a testimony to them.'
verses.comment: Directs obedience to Mosaic Law; demonstrates Christ's fulfillment of the Law, pointing toward the ongoing priestly ministry.

verses.text: When Jesus entered Capernaum, a centurion came to him, pleading for help.
verses.comment: The centurion, a Gentile, demonstrates that faith in Jesus transcends ethnic boundaries, foreshadowing the universality of the Church.

verses.text: 'Lord, my servant is lying at home paralyzed, suffering terribly.'
verses.comment: The centurion's compassion and faith hint at spiritual leadership; note the use of 'Lord' as a title.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'I will come and heal him.'
verses.comment: Jesus' willingness to go to the Gentile's house highlights openness to all peoples and prefigures the mission to the nations.

verses.text: But the centurion replied, 'Lord, I am not worthy that you should come under my roof; but only say the word, and my servant will be healed.'
verses.comment: This phrase is directly echoed in liturgy, reflecting profound humility and faith in Jesus' power through his word alone.

verses.text: 'For I too am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I say to one, 'Go,' and he goes; and to another, 'Come,' and he comes; and to my servant, 'Do this,' and he does it.'
verses.comment: The centurion recognizes Jesus’ superior authority, likened to command but spiritual, hinting at the direct power exercised by Christ.

verses.text: When Jesus heard this, he was amazed and said to those following him, 'Truly I tell you, I have not found such great faith even in Israel.'
verses.comment: Jesus acknowledges the centurion’s faith as outstanding, suggesting faith is not restricted by nationality, anticipating a worldwide community of believers.

verses.text: 'I say to you, many will come from east and west, and will recline at table with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob in the kingdom of heaven.'
verses.comment: Jesus references prophecies of Israel's blessing extended to all nations, prefiguring the united gathering of all believers (see Gen 12:3).

verses.text: But the children of the kingdom will be cast out into the outer darkness. In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
verses.comment: A warning that mere heritage is not sufficient—faith and response to Jesus are necessary for salvation.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to the centurion, 'Go; let it be done for you just as you have believed.' And his servant was healed at that very hour.
verses.comment: Miraculous healing at a distance illustrates Christ's divine power and ability to answer faith-filled prayer.

verses.text: When Jesus entered Peter’s house, he saw Peter’s mother-in-law lying sick with a fever.
verses.comment: Early mention of Peter’s household hints at the beginnings of the apostolic leadership in the broader Christian community.

verses.text: He touched her hand, and the fever left her; then she got up and began to serve him.
verses.comment: Physical healing leads directly to active service, a pattern echoing the spiritual restoration enabling believers to serve.

verses.text: When evening came, they brought to him many who were demon-possessed; and he cast out the spirits with a word, and healed all who were sick.
verses.comment: Jesus' power to heal and deliver emphasizes his supreme authority over both physical and spiritual realms.

verses.text: This was to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet Isaiah: 'He took our infirmities and bore our diseases.'
verses.comment: Direct quotation from Isaiah 53:4, linking Jesus’ miracles to messianic prophecy and showing he fulfills spiritual and physical redemption.

verses.text: When Jesus saw the crowd around him, he gave orders to cross to the other side.
verses.comment: Jesus intentionally moves away from the crowds, reminding us that his mission balanced public ministry and intentional withdrawal for prayer.

verses.text: And a scribe came up and said to him, 'Teacher, I will follow you wherever you go.'
verses.comment: A scribe, typically of Jewish religious authority, expresses willingness to follow, underscoring the universal call to discipleship.

verses.text: Jesus replied, 'Foxes have dens, and birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head.'
verses.comment: 'Son of Man' is a messianic title (see Dan 7:13), highlighting both Christ’s humility and divine identity. Following him requires radical detachment.

verses.text: Another of the disciples said to him, 'Lord, let me first go and bury my father.'
verses.comment: The request shows the pull between familial duty and discipleship; Jesus presents total commitment to his call.

verses.text: But Jesus said to him, 'Follow me, and let the dead bury their own dead.'
verses.comment: Jesus stresses the primacy of spiritual commitments; discipleship demands placing Christ above all else.

verses.text: And when he got into the boat, his disciples followed him.
verses.comment: The disciples' willingness to venture with Jesus symbolically represents trust in his guidance and protection.

verses.text: Suddenly a furious storm arose on the lake, so that the waves swept over the boat. But Jesus was sleeping.
verses.comment: The storm metaphorically reflects life’s trials; Jesus’ calm hints at his divine trust and power over nature.

verses.text: And the disciples went and woke him, saying, 'Lord, save us! We are perishing!'
verses.comment: The disciples' plea is both physical and spiritual, addressing Jesus with a title of divinity and seeking his saving power.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Why are you afraid, you of little faith?' Then he got up and rebuked the winds and the sea, and there was a great calm.
verses.comment: Jesus demonstrates divinity by commanding the elements (see Ps 107:29); faith in him overcomes fear and chaos.

verses.text: The men marveled, saying, 'What kind of man is this? Even the winds and the sea obey him!'
verses.comment: The disciples’ amazement at Jesus’ authority over nature points to his unique divine identity.

verses.text: When he arrived at the region of the Gadarenes, two men possessed by demons came out from the tombs to meet him; they were so violent that no one could pass that way.
verses.comment: This narrative underscores Jesus’ authority over spiritual evil; Matthew mentions two men, differing from Mark and Luke which reference one.

verses.text: Suddenly they cried out, 'What do you want with us, Son of God? Have you come here to torment us before the appointed time?'
verses.comment: The demons recognize Jesus as the 'Son of God,' indicating acknowledgment of his divine status and authority over even supernatural powers.

verses.text: A large herd of pigs was feeding some distance away from them.
verses.comment: Swine, considered unclean in Mosaic Law, further emphasize the Gentile context and the separating of evil from the purified community.

verses.text: The demons begged him, saying, 'If you drive us out, send us into the herd of pigs.'
verses.comment: Even evil spirits must obey Jesus; their dependence illustrates Christ’s ultimate spiritual authority.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Go!' So they came out and went into the pigs, and the whole herd rushed down the steep bank into the sea and drowned.
verses.comment: Jesus’ one-word command echoes divine fiat, further displays of his power over both spiritual and physical realities.

verses.text: Those tending the pigs fled and went into the town, reporting everything, including what had happened to the demon-possessed men.
verses.comment: Eyewitness testimony spreads news of Jesus’ miraculous work; narrative detail emphasizes reality of the event.

verses.text: Then the whole town came out to meet Jesus and, when they saw him, they pleaded with him to leave their region.
verses.comment: Their reaction reflects human fear when confronted with divine authority and power, hinting at the cost of discipleship and the need for spiritual openness.
